void nitf_IOHandle_close (  nitf_IOHandle  handle  ) 
 

Close the IO handle.

Parameters:
handle The handle to close
Returns:
void

nitf_IOHandle nitf_IOHandle_create (  const char *  fname,
nitf_AccessFlags  access,
nitf_CreationFlags  creation,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Create an IO handle. If the file is set to create, the permissions will be built into the create:

See also:
System.h
Parameters:
fname The file name
access The access: valid values include the or'ing of: NITF_READONLY NITF_WRITEONLY NITF_READWRITE
\param error The populated error, only if NITF_INVALID_HANDLE()
Returns:
The fresh handle. Test this with NITF_INVALID_HANDLE()

off_t nitf_IOHandle_getSize (  nitf_IOHandle  handle,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Get the size of the handle (how big is the file). As with the other methods, this function should return a value that is testable with NITF_IO_SUCCESS().

Parameters:
handle The handle to determine the size of
error A populated error if something goes wrong
Returns:
The size of the file

NITF_BOOL nitf_IOHandle_read (  nitf_IOHandle  handle,
char *  buf,
size_t  size,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Read from the IO handle. This function is guaranteed to return after having read the requisite number of bytes or fail out. Check its return value against zero or NITF_FAILURE.

Parameters:
handle The handle to read from
buf The buffer to read into
size The number of bytes to read
error Populated if function returns 0
Returns:
1 on success and 0 otherwise

off_t nitf_IOHandle_seek (  nitf_IOHandle  handle,
off_t  offset,
int  whence,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Seek into the handle at this point. Basically has the same usage as lseek(). If whence is SEEK_SET, the seek pointer is to offset bytes. If SEEK_CUR, start at the current offset and add offset argument. If SEEK_END, the seek is added to the size of the file. On failure, should return a value that may be checked with NITF_IO_SUCCESS()

Parameters:
handle The handle to use
offset The seek offset
whence Starting at (SEEK_SET, SEEK_CUR, SEEK_END)
error The error, if !NITF_IO_SUCCESS()
Returns:
The offset from the beginning to the current position

off_t nitf_IOHandle_tell (  nitf_IOHandle  handle,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Tell the location that the handle is pointing to. On failure, this returns a value that may be checked with the NITF_IO_SUCCESS() macro.

Parameters:
handle The io handle
error The error to populate if there is a problem
Returns:
The offset

NITF_BOOL nitf_IOHandle_write (  nitf_IOHandle  handle,
const char *  buf,
size_t  size,
nitf_Error *  error
) 
 

Write to the IO handle. This function attempts to write to the IO handle until it has written the requisite number of bytes (specified as the size parameter). Upon failure, it returns NITF_FAILURE and the error is set.

Parameters:
handle The handle to write from
buf The buffer to write from
size The number of bytes to write
error The error, only if !NITF_IO_SUCCESS()
Returns:
NITF_SUCCESS if the method succeeds, NITF_FAILURE on failure.
